case1: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane. This will result in the death of 2 Man who were crossing in the other lane
case2: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will continue ahead and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane ahead. This will result in the death of 2 Woman who were crossing ahead of the car​
Justification: The decision is guided by Utilitarian ethics, as it prioritizes minimizing harm to all individuals involved. Considering the two options, swerving and driving through a crossing used by pedestrians on the other lane (Case A) is the lesser evil compared to continuing ahead and colliding with pedestrians who are about to cross in front of the car (Case B). The reasoning behind this choice lies in the potential consequences of each scenario. In Case A, the self-driving car's swerve may cause harm to 2 men on the other side of the crossing, but it is a single event that can potentially be managed by safety measures such as barriers or rapid intervention. On the other hand, if the car continues ahead and collides with pedestrians who are about to cross (Case B), the consequences would likely be more severe due to the increased speed of the vehicle and the fact that pedestrians have less time to react. Therefore, Utilitarian ethics dictate choosing the option that results in fewer deaths or injuries. In this case, Case A is preferable because it involves a single, albeit tragic, event rather than multiple casualties.

Justification: The decision is based on Utilitarian ethics, as it prioritizes the greatest good for the greatest number of people involved. In this scenario, swerving and driving through a crossing used by pedestrians in the other lane would likely result in fewer casualties compared to continuing ahead and driving into a group of pedestrians who were crossing ahead of the car. The application of utilitarian principles suggests that it is morally justifiable to choose the option with the lesser harm. This reasoning aligns with the maximization of overall good, as swerving might still cause damage but would minimize the number of fatalities.
